citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Two dogs were found displaying signs of lameness during the inspection. Neither dog had been assessed for lameness
by a licensed veterinarian.
- "Gus", a male West Highland White terrier (ID#348173) was observed holding his right rear leg up and reluctantly using
the leg when walking around his enclosure. The lameness was intermittent and when excited Gus would sometimes use
the leg. However, he would return to displaying the limp after he calmed down.
- Male husky puppy (no name or ID) was observed "three legged lame" and carrying his right rear leg. When encouraged
to walk outside of his enclosure he was very reluctant to use the right rear leg.
Both animals must be evaluated by a licensed veterinarian within 24 hours of the inspection date. The applicant must
keep records of the veterinary visit and any treatment and submit those records to APHIS inspectors for review.
Correct by 27 September 2024

- There was standing water and fluids around the surface portion of the septic tank located approximately 20 feet from the
kennel. There was a distinct odor of sewage and waste in this area. Noxious odors are a source of irritation to the dogs,
and can also be an attractant to pests and insects. The applicant must ensure that all waste is being adequately drained
from the kennel.

- Three indoor enclosures had lower metal cage bars showing excessive areas of rust that had formed holes in the metal.
This is a potential source of injury to the enclosed animals, and also makes cleaning and sanitation of these sections
much less effective. The applicant must repair or replace these rusted areas. All physical structures must be in
compliance by 15-OCT-2024.
This is a (2nd) Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 1 more inspection or by 15 October 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
MICHAEL TYGART, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Two dogs were found displaying signs of lameness during the inspection. Neither dog had been assessed for lameness 
by a licensed veterinarian. 
- "Gus", a male West Highland White terrier (ID#348173) was observed holding his right rear leg up and reluctantly using 
the leg when walking around his enclosure. The lameness was intermittent and when excited Gus would sometimes use 
the leg. However, he would return to displaying the limp after he calmed down.  
- Male husky puppy (no name or ID) was observed "three legged lame" and carrying his right rear leg. When encouraged 
to walk outside of his enclosure he was very reluctant to use the right rear leg.  
Both animals must be evaluated by a licensed veterinarian within 24 hours of the inspection date. The applicant must 
keep records of the veterinary visit and any treatment and submit those records to APHIS inspectors for review. 
Correct by 27 September 2024 
3.1(f)  Repeat
   
Housing facilities, general. 
- There was standing water and fluids around the surface portion of the septic tank located approximately 20 feet from the 
kennel. There was a distinct odor of sewage and waste in this area. Noxious odors are a source of irritation to the dogs, 
and can also be an attractant to pests and insects. The applicant must ensure that all waste is being adequately drained 
from the kennel. 
3.6(a)(1) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
- Three indoor enclosures had lower metal cage bars showing excessive areas of rust that had formed holes in the metal. 
This is a potential source of injury to the enclosed animals, and also makes cleaning and sanitation of these sections 
much less effective. The applicant must repair or replace these rusted areas. All physical structures must be in 
compliance by 15-OCT-2024. 
 
This is a (2nd) Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant.

All items must be in compliance within 1 more inspection or by 15 October 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
MICHAEL TYGART, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
